species_comments: Pink bill and legs, plain breast and gray face. Was in the large flock of ATSP and DEJU feeding in one of the fields.
Mixed in with the larks, also giving classic twittering call. Will attach pics
In lagoon with ruddy ducks
Seen eating a bird in a tree!
Spread across both ponds, intermixed in larger mixed duck groups or off in smaller groups. Small, brown ducks with pointed tail and males have white cheek patch. Diving.
with canada geese, took off at 954 should be back later today
One male and one female mixed in with mallards along the shoreline of Lake St. Clair
One male and one female swimming with mallards and GWTE.
Hanging near RTL …darker back, shorter bills…sitting higher in water
On Campbell Lake ice, two relatively close to the Bald Eagle.
Landed in tree next to property until crows found it.
Caught a sparrow in my yard and proceeded to eat it.

Immature small white goose with black wingtips, round head and short stubby bill.  Much smaller than nearby immature Snow Goose.  Slight gray spotting evident on top of cute rounded head.   Found on Gull Road just past Zoetis Business, West side of road farm field. Photos to follow.
Large swan with an all black beak with a V shape around the eyes. Seen next to Huron Pointe Excavating with mute swans and tundra swans. Near Harley Ensign off of South River Rd.
Continuing in area. Flew off southeast with Greater White-fronted Geese.
They tend to feed with the gold finch & morning doves. So cool, as this is our first winter (in the 5 we’ve lived here) that we’ve had them at the feeder.
all mobbing the great horned owl that was heard but not seen
Accurate count, mixed with RWBL. Conical-bill, shorter tail, smaller overall size.

Large distant waterbird floating on the water near some Herring Gulls. Obvious loon shape, gray crown and back, and white face and neck were seen. Bill was too large for Red-throated Loon. Photos will be uploaded shortly.

This morning, the usual RUGRs weren’t foraging with the MODOs predawn as has become a typical morning ritual.  But, a RUGR did appear on the disintegrating wood pile out back & began foraging a pile of seeds I had placed on the logs earlier.  It was joined by a BLJA & both foraged the seeds without displacing one another, at times less than an inch apart…never noticed the BLJAs & RUGRs foraging so intimately before (perhaps I just never noticed but today it caught my attention).
First seen this year; on mixed seed and peanut splits; very short visit; none seen later in the day; 2 Common Grackles with them
Small hawk (size of a robin or mourning dove) with obvious square tail did impressive figure eights among the oak tree by the feeders and flew off with a downy woodpecker.
Deep reddish. Heavy eye stripe. No grey ear patch. Reddish flanks to tail coverts. Chunkier than house finch. Occasional at feeder with male house Finches for comparison.
brown streaks on chest, gray on back, small-medium sized falcon, likely female. kicked up mallards. typical bird here. image taken
Continuing. Small white goose with black wingtips feeding on grass with a large flock of Canada Geese near Shelter 10. Stubby bill with no grin line.
Juvenile.  Perched 2" from a hairy woodpecker that flared its wings and stared it down.
With a group of mallards, smaller, very large bill, white breast, brown patch on side, green head

Froze on bark-butter into trance-like, motionless position - suspect defensive, protective measure against presence of RTHA.  Remained immobile for approx. 10 minutes with only slightly discernible head/eye movements (close binocular viewing).
Small grebe.  Stocky head, short bill.  Mingling with mallards and golden eyes. And half their size.  Very brown and a lighter front.
One Greater swimming among the Lessers
Rough estimate of large and small circulating mixed flocks of finches.
Mixed in with bohemians
Soaring over my house being chased by a crow
standing on pier with gulls. see image
Large sparrow, larger than both HOSP and ATSP it was with. Flushed into a bush and didn't see crown. Distinct gray underside and head area. Brown back and white wingbars seen.
Shorebird across the harbor about twice the size of the associating Dunlin or a little bigger. Overall dark brownish in color, long legs, strong supercilium, dark cap.  Photos.
All trying to bathe at the same time
Swooped under the feeder and grabbed a passerine
Pair flying together and calling. Seemed agitated by a pair of RTHA flying nearby.
Together with Common Goldeneyes far out in a water trough in the mostly frozen lake beyond the observation tower, looking south/downstream.
In shallow water with Canada Geese and Mallards
Large dark raptor flying with an immature Bald Eagle. White upper tail with broad dark terminal tail band. White patches in inner primary coverts, golden nape.
With tree sparrows and buntings. Yellow near the eyes with streaking down the chest and flanks. Have pics
flock of at least ten; four briefly landed in the same tree the eagles were in
Foraging predawn w/MODOs…exceedingly skittish though (run or low flight into bush at any disturbance other than MODOs)
Conservative estimate in a huge mixed blackbird flock (probably several thousand) seen foraging in a recently picked corn stubble field.  Photos and video.
4 drakes, at least 1 female in back of marsh on west side of road. Mixed in with large group of mallard and Canada geese.
Still hanging out with the CAGOs along the beach.
Two adults strafing the Common Mergansers, who nevertheless stayed put
Likely mobbing RTHA although might have heard GHOW calls.  Hard to tell with the racket.
calling at same time
Actually saw sharp-shinned hawk close range—stopped in front of us standing on ground w/chickadee in its talons. Sharp-shinned hawk had small head & squarish tail
Continuing- Thank you so much Sue for inviting us over to see these splendid birds! Coming to feeders sporadically with BCCH, photos to be added eventually.
A female type was swimming with 4 Surf Scoters.  Dark brown plump duck with very pale cream-colored  large cheek patch.
Count estimated. Same location as last week’s sightings. Flying together over west lagoon, back and forth, landed together on narrow shore.
Adult Blue morph. Gray body, white neck and head. Pink bill with grin patch. Resting on ice with Canada Geese. Occasionally obscured from view. Photos.
9:17 AM                                                             About five in a mixed flock on Grassy Lake.
Flew into Harbor with CAGO around 5:30, continuing, small white goose with narrow wings, doc photo
In the beach parking lot and south marina parking lot with a huge flock of American trees sparrows.
2 sitting upright on autumn olive in same area with the finch flock on east side of the lake.
Flying over road and to the south. Harassing RLHA
Two Bald Eagles chasing the immature Golden Eagle

Saw from my window looking north over Liberty st. Cruising in on pointed wings, it scattered the starlings from the power lines, then perched a few times in the tall trees along 3rd st and again along Williams st. Got clear perched views in my scope, and could rule out PEFA based on small size, facial markings, and dense upper breast streaks.
2-3000 in raft hugging shore just north of NMC, no doubt some scaup mixed in, but too far to sort with binoculars from across the lake.
Single waxwing with the robin flock in field D
Pecking burning bush together
Large blackbird with long tail and glossy head, yellow eye, larger dark bill than the EUST it was with. Photos.
Foraging, predawn, with MODOs
2 adults and 2 immature. All we’re making passes at Gulls on water.
James called out one in a flock of mostly Lessers
2 Adults, 3 Immatures perched on tree watching Common Mergansers
Mix of Trumpeter and Tundra. Definitely quite a lot of Tundra Swans with yellow lores but also a few immature/adult Trumpeter with larger sloping bills, v-shaped foreheads and larger size
Upside-down “v” pattern on breast, overall reddish tail, back, cheek and wings, gray crown, whitish wing bar.  In meadow edge thicket associating  with DEJU.  Photos to come
1 adult male, cream colored on crown. On fringe of aythya raft.

Never expected to see a shrike in my yard! Gray and brown bird (immature) with black mask, hooked beak, black back, and long tail. Perched in bare tree far enough away so that I had to watch it with my scope rather than binoculars. Calling repeatedly with audio exactly matching Merlin's audio for Northern Shrike but too far away to get good audio. The shrike was also getting harassed by Blue Jays. Lifer!!
Continuing with BB flock
All flew in together.  Have photos
2 drakes and 2 hens. Heard males calling, "buzz-puup". Eventually they flew to the South with several mallards.
feeding on ground with mix of other birds
RUGRs peacefully foraging with MODOs…predawn morning routine
Continuing thrush associating with robins.
M scaup, pointy head, w geese in W lagoon, N end.
Distinctive males, with black bordered whote crest. Females also with brown crest. Smaller than surrounding Common Goldeneye.
All six among assemblage of woodpeckers and nuthatch. Pic
White goose with black wingtips, pink-orange bill and grin patch. Smaller than nearby Canadas.  Pic.
Heard the birds calling and saw them flying side be side with Greater Yellowlegs
Resident female Blue-winged Teal in Pond 9 feeding with Gadwalls

Continuing, seen by many others. Very active upon arrival at 4:30; hunting, flying over the field north of the trail and over the trail about 1 mile west of Dalton. Two owls observed mobbing an annoyed harrier.
41 plus trumpeters in a cornfield along with 35 tundra
Small flock with grackles and starlings
Long spatula like bill. Multiple birds in corn fields with mallards
They spent the morning harassing a peregrine falcon and 2 red-tailed hawks.

Larger than the Tundra swan adjacent to them, more angular bill, the bill was entirely black, the eye was contained in the black of the bill. The Tundra swans eye appears outside the base of the bill making it easier to see it. A clear separation.
Continuing Blue phase with Canada Geese off the NW University campus.
Mixed in with the Mallards
Continuing. Flew in from the north with a flock of Canadas. Small goose almost the size of a mallard, all dark colored with white on its neck.
Spotted a pair of Peregrine Falcons in Royal Oak, MI; one was eating a dove, one was perched nearby on the corner of the building.
Roosting with rusty, red wing, cowbird in trees close to trail

Minimum number.  Two tight groups and several individuals clustered in south part of Vermet Unit.  Mixed with Tundra swans.  Very large birds, large yellow bills, black on wings when raised. Added a blurry photo of one group taken after most of the Tundra Swans had flown from area, but should be sufficient for ID.
Swans smaller than nearby Mute Swans with yellow spot on the lores
Single adult Thayer's form perched on the ice with Ring-billed and Herring Gulls.  The underside of the folded primaries was white.  Eye was dark.

Small accipiter, square tail, fairly large white spots on slate gray back, head with hooded look (vs capped in COHA), possible male. Flying by bird feeder and yew, trying to catch a RBNU that is hanging on to the underside of the bird feeder bar (see photo under RBNU.
Drake; probably same bird continuing from 2 days ago found by Ben Wilson. Feeding amongst several dozen mallards front of Island at the at the Lost Lake and Lost Island trailhead.
Size similar to hawk (nearby crows were slightly bigger than rock pigeons) with hefty large bill curving down. Flight showed curve at wrist.
Chasing the Cooper’s hawk off its roost.
White duck present with mallards
Harassing a Great Horned Owl
Flying over Oakwoods, disturbing geese.
Two adult males. Initially viewed from about 30 yards away. Swimming with Mallards.
Continuing. One owl briefly chased a harrier, then landed and sat on top of post.
Found by Rollin Bresson, really ratty mostly dark juvenile goose associating with Canadas. Pics
Have many around my land. They were chasing the eagle around and a red tail hawk

They covered the top 1/3 of two very large trees.  Flying back and forth to a crab apple tree.  Robins were in a tree behind the house with more CEDW.  Checked closely to see if there were any BOWA but didn't see any.
hanging with two purple sandpipers among the rocks on the Lake Michigan side of the north arm of breakwall. Photos to come.
White phase, mixed with Canada Geese. Black tipped wings . “Grin” on bill

Continuing-swimming with large flock of mallards- much smaller than the mallards, and dark, somewhat drab overall, with a darker head, with a lot of bright white around the outside of the base of the bill. I initially thought greater scaup, as the head seemed round to me, and there was a lot of white at the base of the bill. But after reviewing the photos of other birders, and consulting with them, I have changed my i.d. Special thanks to Isaac Smith.
Was able to definitively ID 2 in the flocks of Horned Larks. Probably a few more, but not many.

Small hawk. Similar to Cooper's but smaller, small "parakeet-like" beak. Also smaller, more rounded head than blocky looking Cooper's. Perched on tree branch near bird feeders. All other birds had vanished.

Owl is tucked into the top of red pine where the branches are the thickest.  Surrounded by crows calling and swarming.  The crows were doing this same behavior at 9:30 am but I couldn’t locate an owl or other cause of their attention.

Flushed up once by Ring-billed seagull on the south pier by the diagonal piece of wood on top of the rocks. Flew up one other time from rocks, otherwise stayed in the rocks not visible from the weather station to the north.
Mixed flock with Red-Winged Blackbirds. Mixture of males and females with distinctive two-tone head and body. Picture taken.
In the same tree; all had heavy sparrow bills, heavy streaking on white chest; grayish faces, reddish cast on back,rump, tail feathers……
Three where I could clearly see a yellow spot at the base of the black bill and eye more separate from bills. With Trumpeters.
Mature eagle being followed directly behind by an immature eagle as the red tailed hawk watched
Cont. Standing on ice with group of Canadian  geese. Orange feet and white at base of beak. Horizontal white line on side.
Very pale Kumlien’s type.  Immature with black bill.  Slightly smaller than nearby HERG, larger than RBGU.  Resting on the Elberta pier with the other gulls. Pics.
Seen in flight together with single LESC; distinguished by size and more extensive white in wing.
Continuing, seen in complex with CANG.  Dark brown head and neck, large orange bill and vertical white stripe in front of eyes.  Black spots on belly.
Swooped down on Mallards.
Harassing Red tailed Hawk
Large, dark-backed divers with sharp elongated beaks, low profile. White upper breast visible at waterline. Feeding together west of marina.
Male and females feeding in scrub close to path, mixed in with mallards. Visible with binoculars and naked eye

Continuing female found by Brian Beauchene yesterday. Diving duck (did see diving) is mottled brown and black overall. Head was a bit lighter brown, whitish over eye and bill is black.  Was seen at a distance with scope required; was with Long-tailed ducks past the green buoy.  Distance was too far for any kind of doc pics.
off cell 3 with goldeneyes
Flock at Point Rosa.

Shout-out to Bobby Irwin for finding three Greater White-fronted Geese in the Huron River next to Riverside Park in Gibraltar. The park is located just north of Pt. Mouillee SGA and Siegler Rd. on the Huron River.--I arrived just before 10 am and found the three geese out in the river among dozens of Canada Geese. These are presumed to be the same 3 birds reported in the Humphries Unit for several weeks now. In fact, after about 5 minutes they flew back toward Pt. Mouillee.
This is not a double count. I have unbelievable amounts of American Goldfinches mixed with Pine Siskins and House Finches.
Flock was in Canadian Lakes.  Bald eagle was hunting them over head as well.
Continuing. Both under feeders.
Approximately. Flocking near/with robins
1 snow goose hanging out with a group of Canadian Geese.

Continuing, robust warbler who was brown above with a white belly with black speckle striping below, unique crown and facial pattern, white eyering. Eating pita bread with Lincoln’s and White-throateds.
Continuing… Blackbird. Distinct brown head with black body. Came it with a flock of starlings to eat on the ground below the feeders.
Both in crabapple tree just outside of the Oryana Coop.
I have a very bad photo. Brown and black speckled back, clearly visible red head, behaving exactly as I would expect a woodpecker to behave. Bigger than downy woodpecker seen on same tree.
Continuing. Mallard size. Swimming together.
1 male in mixed flock of ring-necks and buffleheads
At least 4 males.  Peaked head, compared in direct comparison to GRSC
Mixed flock, mostly Cowbirds, some Starlings, a few Grackles and Red-Winged Blackbirds.

Attention was drawn to a Blue Jay calling overhead and when I looked up it was being chased by the Cooper's Hawk. Much higher up, I saw the Bald Eagle after seeing the COHA. BAEA was a long-overdue new yard bird!
Sleek falcon with gray back and long pointed wigs. Flew south from Shoreline inn area, past Pigeon Hill brewery, and then chased a flock of rock pigeons south
Arrived to feed along with house finches.
At least 1 id’ed in large Canada flocks. Short neck with stubby bill seen on through scope.
Sparrow like bird with unique facial pattern of Longspur, in large farm field with a few Horned Larks.
White goose, smaller than nearby Canada Geese, with black wing tiips, pink bill.
Duck among the swans. Unmistakable cream stripes on head

Mixed in a larger flock of Starlings.  I counted 25 males and a few females.  Males black with brown heads, females more uniformly brownish gray.  I’m sure there were more but Patterson traffic didn’t allow more counting time.
Continuing white phase bird that has been in the vicinity. Flew in with a small group of Canada Geese. It stayed for ~20 minutes and then departed with a flock of CANG.
South of pier parking area, just south of where beach ends. Could be seen from concrete walkway swimming with flock of Canada Geese close to shore. Photos included.
Seen together in former lakebed of Wixom Lake
Observed mixed in with Herring and ring billed gulls near the landfill area

species2_common: house sparrows, juncos, trees sparrows, finches
species_comments: Blackbird spent the morning taking seeds below a sunflower seed feeder with house sparrows, juncos, trees sparrows, finches, etc.

Group of at least 4 mobbing some bird within an evergreen tree, well off of trail. Never got good look at mobbed bird but guessing an owl. Crows chased it to at least 2 other spots where bird landed for a bit/mobbing continued but I never caught up to bird/crows again, though I tried; only heard them for some minutes
All young birds with mostly pink bills except for small dark spots at tips and bases of bill. They were smaller than nearby Mute and Trumpeters.
It was hanging out with a flock of Canadian geese
Together on ground, pecking around driveway dirt
Continuing. Foraging with flock of E. starlings, much larger, blacker and with a much longer tail.
Large number of males and females swimming amongst other mergansers and mallards
Male, all black with an orange knob visible, differentiating it from white winged scoters it was near. No white on back of neck or forehead to void a surf scoter.
Small adult Accip in hot pursuit of BRCR, seen perched showing dark nape
All in view in trees at the same time. Likely more on the feeders.

Many flocks of Horned Larks were flushing from the roadside all along Squawfield Road, stopped occasionally to examine a few of them. A group of 17 just east of the corner of Squawfield and Coman had a meadowlark with them, viewed with bins through windshield, would have left at sp. level but it gave Eastern call as it flushed and flew out of sight behind tall vegetation on the south side of the road.

In with HOLA on Badour north of Kent right where the road turns to dirt. Slightly smaller, darker overall, lacking "horned" look, rattle call in flight.--Possibly a second heard rattling in flight on Kent east of Badour with a group of HOLA, but can't say for certain it was even a LALO, let alone a separate individual.
A female with distinctive white eyebrow, sharply defined side markings. Extensive coloring of males on head and back with minimal or no side striping.  Compared these with House Finches also onsite.
Foraging with MODOs at break of dawn, everyone congregating under front feeders
Small hawk, size of MODO, hunting birds at feeder. Squared off tail.
Small, short-necked w/ stubby bills. Associating closely together among CAGOs. Photos.
In tops of trees with starlings and dove. Long tail was evident. Clearly different silhouette from starlings. Previously seen in neighborhood.
Minimum. Counted individual as the flock fed on the ground before it was joined by the RWBL flock at the DNR parking lot.

Smaller hawk swooping in to catch small songbirds at bird feeders, squared off narrow banded tail, white underbelly with rust plumage and gray body. Wings appeared rounded when in flight, also observed perched in tree.
Flew in to feeder & stayed about 5 minutes eatng. then flew off. longer, more pointed beak than the downies also at feeder.
Continuing.  Medium sized owls, brownish, streaky and buffy undersides.  Popped up briefly when harrier flew over them

*Rare. Crisp first cycle without any signs of preformative molt viewed well in scope with good lighting. Slightly smaller and smaller-billed than surrounding Herrings, although not a very pronounced difference, probably a male. Fairly dark chocolate brown overall with broad white edging on the scapulars. Bill entirely black. Folded wingtips dark brown, darker than body but not black. Tertials with dark centers, not checkered as in Kumlien’s. Never got a look at the spread wing, but nothing about this bird suggested Kumlien’s over Thayer’s. Photos
Female. Has dark brown cap and pale cheek with small and straight bill compared to other scoters. Hanging with a group of common goldeneyes in Ford Lake. Will post photos.
Together along with a LEYE.
Low estimate.  Cinnamon colored birds, black facial mask, crest, white/red markings on wings.  Smaller than Bohemian Waxwings and Starlings that were in the flock.
One with whiter stripe, the other more subtle. Pics. Feeding on sunflower seeds below feeder with house sparrows and cardinals.

As found by Bill Nolting and Donna Parmalee. Not all of its adult/breeding plumage yet, but white dot on face and several stripes nobody- was initially with 3 lesser scaup then flew to the east side of the park/lake. Not leaving right away- swimming and diving. Other birders also following. Too much rain for me- I am soaked!
I observed 1 male Ring-necked duck swimming among the Canadian Geese.
Flying over in mixed flocks of blackbirds. Tail shape and blue-black heads evident.
One flew at perched kestrel, they locked talons and plummeted into a thicket, then gave a bit more chase before going separate ways
Mixed foraging flock with chickadees seen in the tree stands by the crew team parking lot.

Immature Golden Eagle soaring with two Red-tailed Hawks.  Huge dark brown bird with dihedral, isolated large white patch in each underwing , and a pale base to the tail (giving the bird the look of having a wide dark tail band).
Large flock of mixed Waxwings, the vast majority were Bohemian. Estimated total, was probably more.
Photo to follow.  Flew in with Goldeneyes.  Better viewing from end of Hilltop Court just south of Nottingham Park
Floating in water south of pier. Huge in comparison to nearby RBGU.
Morning routine of foraging w/MODOs…predawn
Continuing.  Much smaller than the CANG they were associating with.  Short body, neck and stubby bill.
Pink bill, plain breast, eye ring, gray facial pattern.  Mixed in with a good sized flock of ATSP on the muddy remnants of Oakway Trail.
Continuing from 2 weeks ago? 2 female types swimming near Buffleheads. Large dark ducks, blocky heads, large sloping bills, white patches on side of face and head, no white in wings.
Male, swimming with Mallards and Gadwall

There are many individuals who come and go.  They have been wiping out my sunflower seed on a daily basis.  They are flocked with American goldfinches.  When I walk the dogs, I see and hear quite a few flocks throughout the neighborhoods on the Bluff.
Pair mobbing a Red-tailed Hawk.
Continuing small geese with short necks and bills compared to nearby Canadas.
Estimate counting by 10s
Foraging at the end of the pier with flock of Dunlin
Continuing by canoe dock. Observed sleeping to the right of the Limpkin. See photo. (42.2402082, -84.7401999)
Continuing very far north of pier, swimming alone until flushed and then it returned to the area of the large flock of Canadas.  Distant video through the scope.
Flyby. Heard call, then seen. Identified by voice. Initially being pursued by group of crows (5+), but they soon gave up the chase.
Identification made with assistance of Merlin bird ID; looked like a small group that was spooked up by the juvenile eagles alongside other waterfowl
5 mallard sized geese next to a single CANG making it very see the size difference, short necks and stubby bills
Continuing. In flock with Ring-billed gulls on beach shore. Smaller, all white head, small bill, stout neck, light gray wings. Thank you Vikki Jones for this great find.
In with mallards, green winged teal and mute swans. Small goose with black head, neck, bill, and breast with grayish sides and bright white rear. Continuing. Photo to come.
Flying back and forth at the tree line on the north side of field west of Gotfredson. Two Northern Harriers were hunting in the same area.
Estimated large mixed drift of ducks including Redhead, Canvasback Greater and Lesser Scaup.
all black bills, no yellow- group was separate from a couple of mute swans
came in a mixed flock of red-wings, grackles and mostly cowbirds; definitely grackles with males with purplish head, yellow eyes, long tails
Continuing - Originally in a small strip of open water off of Karen Court Park with 23 Common Goldeneyes, but flew towards the island in the center of the lake where there is more open water.
With large flock of Starlings. Careful count
Scaup, with rather 'peaked in the rear' head shape. About 10% smaller than nearby Redheads
W/snow buntings; both dispersed when a gray ghost showed up
This is a different individual than the BOGU that I noted yesterday which was a first winter gull.   Small gull with black spot on head.  Noticeable size difference with RBGU.
Together at the tip, unmistakable. Pics tba
chase by a crow and blue jay
Foraging along creek with Juncos
Counted individually, mixed in with a flock of HOLA and a few SNBU. Known to be at this location. First of the year!
Keeping close to a pair of mallards
Near barn with starlings.  Pics.
A lone Great Black Backed Gull amongst 100's of Ring-billed and Herring gulls.
Continuing bird associating with large CAGO flock.
Small gull with black patch behind eye and black wingtips. Circling and landing among Gadwall.
Landed briefly by Platt Rd fluddle among crows.
Slightly smaller than Herring Gulls next to it, and with dark grey back, yellow legs. Please see photos.
flew off together very vocally just before Red-tailed Hawk flew through

A spread out flock working its way Southward with individuals flying from tree to tree and on the ground along Kelly Creek for several minutes.  Was able to count individual birds as the flock slowly moved along.  About 20 birds including slate colored Junco, Tufted Titmouse, House Finch,
Seen well with scopes. The two were traveling together. Much larger than the RNGRs with much larger bills.

Associating with a small group of Horned Larks. Sparrow-like bird with dark outline on auriculars, a hint of black on the upper breast, and white on the outer rectrices. Distinctive rattle-like call was heard multiple times.
Continuing. Observed hunting fields, hunting/active flying observed from 9 and still continuing as I left at 10:00 AM. Brief conflict with Northern Harriers in field.
Grey morph. Located by scolding chickadees
Arcadia lake, mixed in. With Greater Scaups. Mergansers are longer so it is hard to be sure.
Continuing; white goose stands out among the Canada geese
Continuing from Window on the Waterfront. Congregating with mallards.
Continuing bird at expected location. Roosting over bird feeders and chasing chickadees.
Male wood duck swimming really close to the two geese. They don’t seem to be bothered by each other. Haven’t seen a wood duck since late summer or fall.
Most I’ve ever seen together, huge groups with a handful of PUFI and AGOL mixed in
Birds hanging out with other divers
Excellent view - yellow wash on sides and yellow rump. Hanging with two eastern bluebirds
Quick stop in yard trees.  Traveling with RWBL.  Photo.
Foraging bark-butter dabs…repeatedly displaced by BLJAs; DOWOs retreat to forage circumfrences of surrounding maples & birches until BLJAs depart & then  return to dabs
At the feeders with the cowbirds this morning.
Continuing in raft of redheads and scaup. Same size as the redheads. Black duck with white cheek patch and erect tail feathers. Reported yesterday by T. Webb.
One group of eight associating with the mallards
Smaller bird than the EUST flock that it was with.  Black body and legs, finch-like bill and brown head.
Feeding on the frozen river with Juncos and Tree Sparrows.
Much smaller than snow goose alongside Canada.
Very large mixed raft with Redheads and Greater Scaup.
Standing on the ice with some Canada Geese

Visual ID and vocal ID. Smaller than accompanying Trumpeters with more concave bill directly at the forehead with a more rounded head. The adults yellow spot on the upper mandible just below the eye was not visible due to distance and sun glare. There were a couple of diagnostic plaintive musical vocal honks given from within the group.
Probably more in a mixed flock with about an equal number of snow bunting’s

All full adults. Out on the ice at least 100 yards from the shore.  Near an open water area.  Two stayed within several meters of each other on the ice for over an hour during my entire walk.  The third skimmed the water several times. Landed again.  And then flew off to the west.  6 crows were on the ice not far away for a while.  Assuming there were some scraps from an eagle's meal.  Picture is distant but shows their location on the ice.
Scaup with peaked head flocking with Greater.
With flock of Snow Buntings
In the road and flying with SNBU in a field west of Gotfredson.
Swimming with LESC in marina. Handsome male, first of the year!

First saw from a distance on Jackson Hole Lake and thought for sure they were ducks, but couldn't ID due to lighting (looking into the sunshine).  When we arrived close to them realized they were 2 Mallard sized geese, same black and white patterned as Canadian Geese. They were near, but not joining, 4 Canadian Geese, which made comparison easier.  Their heads were much rounder than the flatter longer head of the Canadian, also had shorter stubby bills and their necks were only half the length of the Canadian's (6 inches vs. 12 inches).
3 on Fountain pond mixed with flock of redhead
Brown heads clearly visible amongst blackbirds clearly viewed in roadside tree.

Continuing at bark butter applications; mostly at front feeders that offer more protection than the open back deck feeder area.   Suspect these are the same BOCH that have been on the property since at least November 2022, on a daily basis.  Occasionally, accompanied by a third, but general sightings of 1 or 2 together, at the same time, throughout the day.  I’ve attempted to time their visits & it appears that they forage on the bark butter & peanut pieces for a few minutes, then disappear, only to return in approx. 30 minutes to an hour and begin feeding again.  Usually accompany BCCHs.  However, the property is now closed to any & all visitors.  No Trespassing signs are posted in driveway.  Given the few days of warm weather, & then freezing nights, the shoveled pathways I was attempting to maintain are now ice slicks & I cannot ensure any visitors’ safety (&, knowing of these hazardous conditions, and as owner of the property, I am legally liable for any injuries that could occur - I personally wear ice cleats when I venture outside).   I’d like to thank everyone who stopped by to see the BOCHs - it was a pleasure.
More robins and cedar waxwings than I can count in upper branches of trees with berries.
Heard their chet calls along with white winged, audio upload coming.
Viewed near potential SBAG, adult slightly smaller than nearby herg. Known roosting site
Continuing with common mergs and goldeneyes
Eating berries with the cedar waxwings
Continuing. Smaller version of Canada Goose, with short neck and stubby bill. On ice sheet near mix of Mallards and Canada Geese.
With mixed flock at the Nature Center feeders

Single tundra swan mixed in with a large group of trumpeter swans. Younger individual, with grey feathers on the neck and head, as well as the “swooped” bill and more prominent eye characteristic of the species.
Together along the first bridge
At least. Along with the RWBL.
At least 2 seen with the Mallards & Canada Geese
Seen flying with GOEA.

Small bird with thin bill, yellow crown, rump, and below rhe shoulders, striped along the flanks, white tips on the outer corners of the tail. Foraging with mixed flock, both on the ground and in the trees. I was hoping for a pine Siskin when I got my first glance since I never got one last year. Oh, well!
Male wood duck hanging out with mallards. Smaller then mallards with fancy green crest.
Mixed flock of EUST, RWBL, COGR, BHCO
All white herons on north side of road; west side of the spit of land that the cormorants are roosting on.
Count is estimate; males and females swimming amongst mergansers and mallards
Continuing, flew through the yard and into the thicket by the river. The house Sparrows went silent. Small accipiter - blue jay size, long squared off banded tail. Hunts here very frequently.
Numerous individuals mixed in among Horned Lark flock.
Three males swimming together; reddish brown body, black head with large white patch, white breast with 2 vertical dark stripes, thin bill.  Smaller than nearby COME
heard it, i believe it was following the hawk for food
Very large flock of cranes with the geese.
Angled head, purplish iridescence. Great light with GRSC nearby for comparison.
Continuing here. Mixed among other species
Female. Chocolate brown head, black bill with white patch at base. Body darker brown on back and lighter on sides. Smaller than MALL around it.
Predawn foraging under front feeders with MODOs
White, mixed in with flock of Canada Geese.
Continuing. Small dark goose slightly larger than Mallards and smaller than nearby Canada Geese. North side of pier.
Small white goose with black on wings, flying with Canada geese
Mixed flock of cowbirds and blackbirds. Recognized by red-orange stripe on wing and distinctive calls.
Creamy pale subadult gull with light scalloping, pale wingtips, black bill tip, about the same size as nearby herg
Loudly calling as it was chased by smaller American Crows also calling.  Significant size difference and differentiated calls

Buffy streaked owl with clear facial disk and dark eyes. Hunting field and briefly fought with Northern Harrier. Owl flew in front of our parked vehicle. Lots of close looks in the binoculars. Continuing at this location.
In with group of Greater Scaup. Ring on bill clearly visible.
Counted 15-20 with the COGO
Orange bills, white faces. Brownish overall, smaller than adjacent CANG.
Mixed in with Black Ducks near toll booth, on lake where Osprey nest
2 male 1 female. Swimming next to a flock of mallards. Small duck, brown head with green eye swatch.
Lone bird way out fishing by gulls.
Black bodies with brown heads. In with starlings.
I was happy to see these, been a while and reminded me of Maryland.  Two birds associated with mallards in Lake area along entrance drive.
Feeding in the road with tree sparrow
Continuing  east side of road. Flew off with Canadian  geese.

Unexpected, especially as they were flying over the lake. Mobbed by a flock of ~40 AMCR at around 7:35. Rounded, tannish wings evident in flight with well-patterned underwings. Accompanied by a second a few minutes later, where they tangled in flight and disappeared soon after.
At least 4 females and 1 male clearly seen, but likely more. Mixed together with larger flock of House Sparrows.
Good look at close range when all were flushed by an eagle
Flew into next door neighbor’s trees along with 2 Starlings. Fourth time for Robins in the yard area since the first of the year.
All in view at the same time in the west cove.

Proportional estimate, in a big mixed flock with trumpeters in a picked corn field. Species separated by relative size, pattern and shape of bill/face/eye, and presence of yellow lore on some of the tundras.
Adult perched in tree, over looking Mallards
Late. Foraging alongside Snow Buntings.
mixed in flock of snow buntings, in field
White morph, swimming with larger CANG. Distant photo attached.
Foraging w/MODOs…congenially congregating, no displacements - daily morning routine
Continuing here regularly all winter, usually at first light with the tree Sparrows. Striped breast central dark spot

Swimming around large group of Canada Geese at the very back of the marsh - very small gull, smaller than Hering and Ring-billed Gulls also present, small black bill, black ear spot. These gulls have been reported in this location by other birders in recent days.
Male swimming with mallards and black ducks. Clear green eye marks and white forehead, white rump.
in with raft of ducks. male, distinctive head plainly visible. Noted by another birder the same day.
The hawk was in my cedars by observing a Hairy and Downy woodpecker. They did not move from my suet feeders for more than 20 to thirty minutes. Then I saw it sitting and eating in the redbud tree

2 mixed in among the tundra swans, continuing from another birder's observation yesterday. These individuals are  more stout than the Tundra Swans. Dusky reddish hue to head, eye is less prominent than on tundras, no yellow on bill present and border between bill and face is straighter.

This is a mature female who has been seen quite often this winter. Feeding on the ground under the hanging feeders or on the ground under a nearby mature spruce tree. Never comes alone, frequently in the company of Cardinals.

Heard calling while checking power line outage. A deep crackled “craw” came from a ways to the northwest and just after a scolding high pitched “caw caw” from that same vicinity. The deep call came from a CORA, which I’ve heard many times, the higher pitched was an AMCR.
Small female nuthatch in tree with muted reddish breast, bluish back and wings, black stripe across the eye. Smaller than the nearby white-breasted nuthatch.
Mixed flicks in the area
Side by side with greater yellowlegs
Will add photos. Tiny geese overhead w Canada’s
western edge of prairie, edge of swapmp, with cardinals and juncos

Flagged as high count. On the large pond by the recycling center, with Redheads. Flock moved frequently, flying from one end of the pond to the other, and a couple times circling over the pond in scattered groups for several minutes. Counted birds individually. Photos.
Continuing, seen at the same time
Flew south with a flock of gulls.  Noted the ear patch and weak "M" marking on back.
In with flock of Hooded Mergansers - larger, log thin bill, head dark with shaggy bad hair day crest, male - dark reddish breast, females - grayish breast, no white on throat like Common Merganser
Continuing, foraging far out on shore with Canada Geese, north of the pier.
Originally picked up by Merlin and then seen moving with chickadee and titmice in tree canopy.
Similar in size to the mute swans, it was associating with, larger than the tundra. Straight black bill.
Lone bird beyond pond nearest Haslett Road.  A 'where’s Waldo' challenge in the midst of many Canada Geese.  Continuing. Grainy high ISO pictures below.
Flew in to mat feeder on deck with three grackles. Black birds with red and yellow wing bars
Larger numbers mixed withs Mallards on ice and in open water.
Hanging out with Canada geese. Black wingtips, grin visible.
Continuing.  Large Grebe with white cheek, black cap and long yellow bill.  Easy comparison with nearby HOGR.
Four crows were chasing this red-tailed hawk over the west woods.
Male In tree near Downy which really showed size difference
Both flew to the same tree along with the RBWO.

Seen well - pictures to follow.  Goose larger than the Mallards that it was foraging with - all dark head--and neck with defined separation between gray/brown back, white under tail coverts.  Continuing.
Continuing. With Common and Hooded Mergansers. Photos.
Continuing immature under feeder with house sparrows.
Small accipiter with hood; successfully hunted a Tufted Titmouse.

1 adult female observed near Mallards in the large pond at the park. Seemed to be alone (only one if it’s kind). Much smaller than the Mallards surrounding her. Was attempting to dive in the pond. Had gray bill with white base. Had yellow/orange eyes, brown head and chest with buffy brown/ gray body. Pictures will be added soon.

Standing on ice at edge of water where Huron River blends into Kent.Lake, They and most of the Canadas they were with flew off while I was walking to get my camera.  Geese with orange legs white forehead pinkish bill brown body with diagnostic black speckling on belly.

Continuing.  Small hawk, slightly smaller than a crow, swooped by our bird feeders and landed on the ground under an ewe evergreen bush that the small birds like to congregate. Could see gray back and wings, gray and black striped, square tail. When it didn't arouse any birds into flight it flew up to a tree branch were its small gray head, orange barred breast, white rump and yellow legs and feet were visible. After about 10 seconds it flew off into the woods to the west. Total sighting was approximately 25 seconds.
Likely the same first year bird reported from this morning. Huge white behemoth with light wingtips feeding and resting on the tarp. Larger than nearby herrings. Pics
Mixed with bonies. Photo.
4 flew in honking others in open pond mixed groups  with mute.
Continuing white goose with black tips, smaller than CAGOs it was with, ‘slimmer’ than domestic; as seen in farm field north side of Geddes between Brookside sub and Harris rd
Pair foraging and zzt calling back and forth. Almost got caught by a Cooper’s right in front of my face
Sitting together in hedgerow. FOY, Well you take the good with bad as spring begins to appear on the horizon.
actual count, together on side of road

Group of 4 similarly plumaged females east of pier. Viewed from 50m with binocs/scope. Upturned bill more prominent than those of nearby bufflehead, dark. Dark cap extending down nape. Whitish cheek area noticeable under cap. When they took flight, showed all dark, though lighter color cheek/face still distinguishable.

Adult bird flying for about an hour with a group of Bonaparte’s Gulls over the marshes on the eastern side of Anchor Bay.  Slightly smaller than the BOGU; rounded wings with dark black underwings and pale upper wings with no leading white edge and no black primary tip on upper wing.  Bird about half-mile out so scope views required but views clear.  No photos obtained.  Also seen by 3 other observers before view obscured by snow squall then could not be re-found.
A black iridescent bird with a long tail and yellow eyes. It was thrashing through the leaves along with the robins.  I took a photo.
mig with group of WWSC, ph--Dark-winged scoter with chunky, longish head and bill, and the appearance of opague remiges in bright sunlight.
Resting on bank at Thorrington Lake.  Long Sloping black bill, pointed forehead, able to distinguish between Mutes, and the Tundras nearby by bill comparisons.
Seen with mallards, just off the sidewalk area with railings. Smaller goose with white rump and white marking on bill..
Mature male caught a mourning dove, dove is almost the same size as the hawk as seen in the not great pic.
Was hanging around a group of adult Herring Gulls but had noticeably darker back as well as yellow legs
First year male appearing with tree sparrows

Continuing. Viewed through scope, from great distance, seemingly near Grand pointe Park. Moved from Nottingham Park, to attempt better views and it was absent from the group of Golden Eyes that it had been swimming with (hence no photo, or a very poor one possibly later).
One male two female in a big group of common goldeneye and American black duck
Soaring together. Noticeable dihedral.

species2_common: Canada geese, mallards, mute swans, tundra swan
species_comments: Large group at the edge of the pack ice on the river. Grouped together with a large number of Canada geese, mallards, several mute swans and  a single tundra swan.

Jit jit calls while flying over--At the Valley Road stop, the call lacked the buzzy, upward-inflected notes of PISI, or the chatter of CORE. I used Merlin to confirm my suspicions of WWCR instead of the clearer "twit" note of RECR. Same call was heard at other stops. In Maple City, we saw 5 at the tops of spruce trees, and they flew off giving the same call. At Century Rd, a group of 20 flew in calling, and we almost got a look before a Merlin chased them off.
A few mixed in with other RWBLs Starlings and Cowbirds.
They were looking for food in my yard with some juncos.
Rusty cap, pinkish bill. White eye-ring. With juncos and tree sparrows
Female at feeder with sparrows, all field marks confirmed
aythya ducks with peaked rear crowns and whitish sides. With rndu flock

Continuing. Conspicuously smaller than the other geese as they grazed side-by-side (not much larger than the mallards), sharper angle between bill and forehead, shorter bill, thinner legs (could be related to being smaller overall)
Plump shorebird with dark grey upper, orange base on bill, foraging along the water edge by the sea gulls! Continuing on the north side of the pier towards the condos
Small sized between blue jay and crow.
Feeding on  with White winged Crossbills.
Loose flock. Perched in tree above nearby houses.

First winter. Size between nearby Ring-billed and Herring, and giving a petite impression when compared to the Herring Gull. Pale overall with no black in the wingtips, so likely to be a Kumlien's. Smallish all black bill

Just a tiny bit larger than the Mallards present. Short necks. Tiny bills. Seen through a scope. --These geese were counted by ones using a Swarovski scope to scan through the individuals present. What was most noticeable to me was that there were no large geese (Canada Geese) present so size was determined by comparing the geese to the mallards that were also present and noting that they were almost identical in size. We studied these geese through a scope. None of us has a camera that could reach out that far.  I am not good at estimating distance but try to think in terms of football fields. I believe that the birds were at least 1 1/2 to 2 football fields away, maybe farther. Ric might be able to give a better estimate of the distance out.
Mixed in with a flock of red winged blackbirds
Huge number mixed in with redheads, estimate likely conservative
Continuing. Flying together and calling out.
Male, yellow bill, hanging out with group of mostly male Mallards
Several pairs and small groups (4-6) throughout the facility among huge flotillas of Northern Shovelers
Mostly brown geese with white face and orange bills. Noticeably smaller than the Canada's next to them. Pics through the snow are rough, but can see the face.
Mixed flock in trees NE of DNR office

Dark diving ducks with striking white patches on their secondaries, which was apparent when they dove and fluttered their wings. These are likely the same birds that were reported yesterday at the same location my Amy Lyyski.--The birds were located fairly distantly toward the NE and were actively diving throughout the observation period. They were initially associating with a single SUSC and were several dozen meters north of a couple SUSC. However, the SUSC eventually shifted north and at the end of the observation period, the six scoters were associating as a single group.
Continuing bird found by Lorri Wallet. With Canada Geese near picnic shelter #10
Large dabbler in small flock of Mallard. Darker body and flanks, light brown head, yellow bill. Slightly larger than female mallards nearby.

Probably the same group that Bruce has seen the past two days at various spots around the lake. Loosely associating with a group of hooded merganser. BLSCs were larger. Dark overall with pale cheek. Larger than RUDU would be and more upright. Didn’t have the low to the water look that I associate with RUDU. Too distant for photos.

Heard several barking calls at dusk, then located one owl in flight - characteristic irregular flight pattern with several glides mixed in, choppy wing beats, swooping and turning. Buffy patches on forward primaries (outer wing). Second owl found perched on a wooden fence post, where we were able to use the scope for good looks. Darker upper body was facing us, and pale rounded facial disk visible when looking at us, showing dark markings only around the eyes. Lighter facial disk than long-eared, great-horned, or barred owls. Similar in size to the Northern Harriers also hunting in the same fields.
Mixed in with a small flock of Common Goldeneyes
Black streaks in head and bright white throat. Mixed with several tree sparrows and goldfinches at feeder.
Clear view of male redhead, diving with scaups. Dark red head, dark grey tail and breast, light gray flanks. Bluish beak.
The sound of many geese headed over this observer from behind the building was overwhelming, only to see a very different bird soaring high above and behind the flock.
Large, all pale gull resting on tarp, larger than nearby HERG. No black wing tips. See photo.
Scattered along a large raft of mixed Common Goldeneyes and Greater Scaup. The most I have seen in this location, but it is a common site to find this species this time of year.
Female with redheads. Large uniformly dark black duck with large pale face patch.
Estimate. Large mixed flock of Horned Larks and Snow Buntings with a few Lapland Longspurs
With flock of House Sparrows. Rust and grey scratching ground around feeder. Flock left and one remained much longer.
All dark bills no yellow lores. Not smaller than the MuSW nearby
Saw 2 on the lake with Ring-necks and a flock of 78+ flew overhead but didn't land
Two adult pair, with three immature.  One pair close enough to see yellow spot on bill, the other pair more distant, but noticeably smaller to very nearby mutes.
Spread across both ponds, intermixed in larger mixed duck groups and off in smaller groups. Small ducks with large white head patch (males) and small white cheek patch (females). Dive often.
Known location. Green and brown headed duck feeding in muddy edge of pond with a group of mallards. Audio recording verified.
Heard calling with flock of ATSP.
Rounded head. Near lesser scaups.
Mixed with Goldfinches in Alders and Yellow Birches.
Feeding on the birch seeds with the goldfinches
Female red-bellied flew in and drove off 2 doves and a male hairy, though it took a few tries to get the doves to leave.

Watched a bald eagle take a female out of the lake and eat it in a tree. The eagle snatched it out of the water and carried it to a branch by its head. The duck fought for a good 8 minutes on the branch (+another few minutes when the eagle was diving underwater to get a grip on it), flapping its wings and kicking the eagle on the branch with feathers being plucked out of it before it finally died. Horrible way to die.
Chunky blackbird with brown head, black body. Two mixed in flock of Red Winged Blackbirds. Eating on ground.
On tree near feeder with 1Downy, 1 Red Bellied Woodpecker
Mix of males and females with goldeneyes. Black in front and back, whitish in middle. Some males visible with purplish sheen on head.
Together. Roosting on point of land near shoreline.

Mixed flock of Snow Buntings, Horned Larks, and Lapland Longspurs flying  north and south over harvested fields on Vreeland west of Gotfredson, before the farm. Landed on road for short time before flying off again.

species2_common: Ross's goose, CAGO, mallards, sandhill cranes
species_comments: Immature. Darker and larger than nearby immature Ross's goose. Dark bill. Foraging corn stubble with CAGO, mallards, sandhill cranes and ross's goose. See pics.
Drake Woodie mixed in with the Mallards. Has been here for several days
An all white feathered swan large or larger than the Mute Swans near it, with a thinner neck. Large all black bill and black legs and feet. Pics to be added.
Estimate by 10s. Flock flushed by COHA
Popped up on top of a winterberry next to a pond with Cardinal and tree sparrows. Distinct male in full color. Black, white, and orange sides
One pair was swimming at the west end of the lake by themselves. There were 3 other pairs swimming along the south shore of the lake among several Canadian Geese.
Est in Mixed flock with Juncos and ATSPs in field beyond woods
All together in a marsh. See pics.
Mixed flock of about 40 birds- Starling, Redwing Blackbirds
flying in groups with geese
Sitting side by side.
2 m, 2 f separate but close to GADW.
continued ---
Short square tail, small head, pursuing small bird at about 25 feet off the ground.  Fast glide separated by frequent quick wingbeats.
4 females and 3 males mixed in with mallards and Canada Geese in the pond on the south end of Swanson Road
Amazingly, this Merlin is still hanging around. It’s been in the area – my neighborhood – for more than a month now. It was harassed by two crows this morning.
It was unusual, but not unheard of to see a Canvasback in the large flocks of Redhead.
Dark morph adult. With trumpeter swans.
sitting together in tree
Flock with AMGO foraging in cedars on cones and calling frequently. Many cone scales on forest floor as indication that flocks were feeding throughout the area.
Immature soaring over the large farmer's field near Hickman, guarded by many crows

Massive flock of blackbirds, volume growing every visit.  Picture of one tree full of blackbirds, at least 8 trees full of birds, with hundreds more streaming in and out.   Over 100 COGR mixed in, a couple of RUBL, one YHBB, and small amount of BHCO.
Harried by the harrier.
A handful mixed in with the grackles
Female present with mallards
Swimming along with the Scaups.
Counted by ten’s.  Will get more accurate count later from photos.  Larger than adjacent CEDW.
Continuing.  Large Dark Ducks with white wing patches visible while swimming and flying.  Nice comparison with nearby SUSC.
Black bill, trumpeting. Lots, with geese and mallards.
Smaller than the other Canadian Geese they were swimming near. Shorter snub tip beak.
Rusty cap, black eyeline, foraging with juncos.
2 white, 1 blue phase; with CAGO.
All black bird, yellow eye, smaller than crow. Was foraging in mud with juncos and tree sparrows

Fairly regular occurrence are these HOFI flocking up alongside EUST with a small handful of HOSP in the CEC Podium parking courtyard, with the bulk flocking up in the east courtyard with the building.

Had to push our way through bushes and branches to walk upstream along Mallets Creek. Several flocks of robins, starlings, and cedar waxingwings were flying across Mallets Creek back and forth perching and making loud calls. Almost reminiscent of Hitchcock's The Birds.
4 dark morph 2 white. Landed with Canada geese. I took a photo with my scope.

Slightly smaller Laris gull among Herrings. Light brownish-gray body and head overall, thin and long bill that is light pink with dark tip. More pink than gab is typical so possibly early second cycle bird. Pale brown primaries with crisp white edging to them. Dove-like head shape with more calm looking demeanor compared to less rounded head shape of Herrings.
Single Ross mixed with Canadas feeding in turned corn field. Mallard size. Short orangish pink bill. Black wing tips. No “grin” like a Snow. Tom Healey also observed Ross at this location.

*Rare, possibly continuing. Spotted by Todd Palgut sitting on the ice, all together in a group. Very small white-cheeked geese with tiny bills and short necks, much smaller than surrounding CANGs. Photos
Group of 6 keeping separate from Canadas.  Smaller birds, shorter bills.
Estimate.  With bohemian waxwings feeding in crab apple tree and roosting in poplar trees between dives into crab.
Pic. 5 of them with the mallards across from the beavers den. Nesting in the reeds arround the small island with three trees surrounded by water.
Medium sized gull. Completely pale wingtips. Bill a dull yellowish grey. Noticeably different than nearby RBGU.
Continuing. It does not blend in. Stark white in a sea of Canada geese.
Heard rattle calls at Long Skinny Park/Hamlin lake. Foraging high in tree tops with a group kf blue jays. Adult. Solid red head, prominent white patch in wings.
Large group feeding on berries.  Juncos mixed in.
Observed together in woodland along river front; characteristic front spots and black crescent observed.
Hangs out with the robins
Possibly more.  Associating with the Ross’s and close in size to that bird.  Short neck, rounded heads and stubby bill.
They were very vocal on the water and stayed separated from the mute swans.
25-35 visit daily with the evening grosbeaks.
Huge mixed flock with snow bunting and Lapland longspur
*Scarce in winter. Small sparrow with long tail, small pink bill, brown upperparts, unmarked gray below, and a prominent white eye-ring in with a flock of ATSPs

Pale breast with dark spots, brown back and reddish tail, complete gray eye ring. On ground poking through leaves where snow has melted. Heard soft chuck calls before spotting. Smaller than Robin (which was also in the area during the checklist).
Continuing. Photos. Short, snubby bill, short neck, size far smaller than CANG, slightly larger than Mallard. Pictured together with a slightly larger Snow Goose.
Continuing. Seen to the north from end of the pier with Canadas and Mallards. Finally! :) lifer! Photos to come.
Mixed in with larger gull group. Darker than surrounding Ring-bills and Herring, but not quite as large looking as the Herring Gulls. Did not seem to have the darkness of a great black-backed.
Flyovers in groups with Canada Geese
Cont. Pic. Mixed with tree sparrows, in and under birch trees, W side of fish cleaning parking lot.
all thick black bill, straighter neck than mutes, was with a few mutes, body different, bigger looking than tundras. was seen in area earlier in the year.
Slightly larger than RBGU, slightly smaller than HEGU.  Small round dove like head.  Gray back with some dark in primaries.  South end of beach on the sandbar with other gulls.
Hanging out with the coots
